step_goal: Wash the vegetables at the sink.
rationale: Cleaning the vegetables is a necessary hygiene step to remove surface dirt and contaminants before chopping and cooking.

causal_precondition_on_affordance.reasons: The tap must be active and releasing a stream of water to enable the rinsing action.
The vegetables must be held securely to be manipulated under the water stream.

causal_effect_on_affordance.reasons: Exposure to the running water removes surface debris and wets the skin of the vegetables.

counterfactual_challenge_question: If the water pressure were extremely low (just a dribble), would this step be effective?
expected_challenge_outcome: No, the mechanical force of the flowing water is required to effectively rinse away dirt particles; a dribble would be insufficient.

failure_reflecting.reason: The water stream might deflect off the curved surface of the vegetables, causing splashing onto the counter.
failure_reflecting.recovery_strategy: Lower the hands deeper into the sink basin or adjust the angle of the vegetable to direct the splash downwards.

critical_frames.action_state_change_description: Initiation: The agent positions the first vegetable (zucchini) under the running water stream to begin rinsing.

causal_precondition_on_affordance.reasons: The tap must be active and releasing a stream of water to enable the rinsing action.
The vegetables must be held securely to be manipulated under the water stream.

causal_effect_on_affordance.reasons: Exposure to the running water removes surface debris and wets the skin of the vegetables.

hotspot.description: The outer skin/surface of the zucchini positioned in the water flow.
hotspot.mechanism: Fluid flow exerts shear force to remove contaminants from the object surface.

critical_frames.action_state_change_description: Completion: The agent finishes rinsing the second vegetable (carrot), ensuring all items are cleaned.
